conclusion: The task is to predict which container (D or E) the liquid from A, B, and C will flow into after passing through baffles.
The solution involves analyzing the flow paths of liquids from containers A, B, and C through the baffles to determine which collection containers (D or E) will receive the liquid.
The first image shows the initial setup with three liquid containers at the top (A, B, C), various angled baffles (colored bars) in the middle, and two collection containers at the bottom (D, E).
The second image shows the actual flow patterns with colored streams flowing from each container, interacting with the baffles, changing direction, and eventually reaching the bottom containers.

Liquid from container A (teal/turquoise) starts flowing downward, hits the purple baffle, gets deflected to the right, continues downward, hits the gray baffle, and ultimately flows toward the middle/right side of the board.
Liquid from container B (yellow) flows downward in a relatively straight path, hits the gray baffle, and gets directed toward the right side.
Liquid from container C (blue) flows straight downward, does not appear to hit any baffles directly, and maintains its rightward position.

The teal (A) and yellow (B) liquids both get redirected by the gray baffle toward the right side, and the blue (C) liquid maintains its rightward path. All three streams appear to converge toward the right side.
The collection containers are D (yellow/orange container on the left) and E (green container on the right).

Based on the flow patterns visible in the second image, all three liquids (A, B, and C) will flow into container E (the green container on the right). None of the liquid appears to flow into container D (the yellow/orange container on the left).
